field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: On 25 September 2024, the MoH of Burundi officially declared the MPOX epidemic outbreak. The daily SitRep (No055) published on 18 August 2024 shows 614 cumulative cases recorded in 35/49 Health Districts, and 312 cases are still active.
field_reports.description:
Burundi faces many threats from diseases with epidemic potential. After a few weeks of suspected cases of monkeypox (MPox), Burundi declared a Mpox epidemic on July 25, 2024. Burundi's border with the Democratic Republic of Congo constitutes an MPox epidemic zone.  
The overall secondary attack rate after contact with a known human source is 3% (study conducted in South Africa in 2023), and attack rates of up to 50% have been reported in people living with persons infected with MPox.
As of July 22, 2024, three alerts from the Kamenge University Hospital Center (CHUK), the Kamenge Military Hospital (HMK), and the ISARE Health District reported suspected cases of MPox. 
The cases generally presented symptoms such as fever, skin rashes of sudden onset and paroxysmal appearance, lesions of the oral cavity, headaches, physical asthenia, and dysphagia.
The tests from the national reference laboratory confirmed the monkeypox virus for these 3 cases. 
Two positive cases were reported on July 22, one of which was in the Kinama zone of the Bujumbura Nord health district, the other in the SHATANYA 4 district of the city of Gitega and a third case was confirmed in the Tenga district. Local Isare district. These three cases are handled at CHUK (2) and HMK (1).
On 18/09/2024, 15 new confirmed cases were reported. The cumulative suspected cases are 1683 cases, of which 614 cases have been investigated and validated.

results.name: BDI: 2024 Floods Simplified Early Action Protocol
results.summary:
Due to its quasi-tropical climate, Burundi is at enormous risk of flooding all year round, but flooding is particularly concentrated during the two rainy seasons (September to November and February to June). It should be noted that an increase in the risk of extreme rainfall caused by climate change could change this picture and cause the risk of flooding to be considered widespread. It could also have a greater impact if they affect communities with little experience of this kind of disaster. 

Riverine and urban flooding, the most common type of flooding in Burundi, is characterized by the overflowing of riverbeds due to heavy (and sometimes long-lasting) rainfall in the various catchment areas. This type of flooding affects the communities that live or carry out their economic and subsistence activities on the banks of these rivers. These floods cause enormous human and material damage. In particular, the Burundi Red Cross has listed the primary impacts as deaths and injuries, the destruction of private and public infrastructures, and the overflowing of latrines. Agricultural and forage fields are often flooded, resulting in crop and livestock losses, and households are often displaced in the short and medium (and sometimes long) term. Secondary impacts cascade down, the most important of which are food insecurity, the outbreak of water-borne diseases, and a host of socio-economic and psychosocial impacts.

These situations impose a clear need for assistance, which can be summed up mainly in the following actions, by the various agencies and organizations (including the Burundi RC (CRB)) involved in disaster management. National and provincial platforms play an important role in coordinating emergency response.

field_reports.description:
En date de 20 Avril 2024, sur la colline Gabaniro de la Commune Muhuta dans la province Rumonge, un glissement de terrain a provoqué  les dégats suivants:

-Une personne décédée (un enfant de 4 ans)

-4 personnes blessées

-497 maisons detruites

-2485 personnes déplacées

-700 Ha de champs endomangés

-Une base vie de la société Kirasa énergie destruite

-Une adduction d'eau en eau potable endomagée, deux reservoirs detruits et1 station de pompage  en eau

-3 pylônes éléctriques haute tension

-2 Eglises

-1 mini central hydrau-éléctrique de Mutumba

Une grande partie de la population déplacée est logée dans les salles de classe du Centre de métiers de Gitaza et une autre partie dans les ménages d'accueil.

results.name: BDI: Landslide - 04-2024 - Bdi Landslide-April-2024
results.summary:
On April 20, 2024, on Gabaniro Hill in Muhuta Commune in Rumonge province, a landslide caused  the following damage:

-A deceased person (a 4-year-old child)

-4 people injured

-497 houses destroyed

-2485 displaced persons

-700 ha of damaged fields

-A remote site of the Kirasa energy company destroyed

-A water supply with damaged drinking water, two destroyed reservoirs and 1 water pumping  station

-3 high-voltage electricity pylons

-2 Churches

-1 mini hydro-electric power plant from Mutumba

A large part of the displaced population is housed in the classrooms of the Gitaza Career Centre and another part in host households.

field_reports.description: During the night of 06/01/2024 to 07/01/2024, heavy rain fell on the mountains overlooking the hills of NYAMITANGA and NDAVA Village in the BUGANDA commune, Cibitoke province, as well as the Gihanga and Buringa hills in the Gihanga ommune and the Musenyi hill in the Mpanda commune, both in the Bubanza province. These rains caused landslides that blocked the Bujumbura-Cibitoke road at the very spot where the disaster occurred, and caused flooding downstream in the plains, resulting in the destruction of houses and fields, as well as other damage of various kinds, including the destruction of homes and the displacement of the population. These floods also caused the latrines on the NYAMITANGA hill to overflow, which is a predisposing factor for epidemic diseases caused by dirty hands, such as cholera, which was prevalent in this commune.

field_reports.description:
Dans la nuit du 3 au 4 Avril 2023, la rivière Rusizi a fait un débordement qui a causé des inondations dans 5 collines de la Zone Gatumba. Suite à la récurrence et la gravité de la situation humanitaire, la Plateforme National de Prévention et réponse aux catastrophes du Burundi s’est réunie dans les enceintes de la CRB et a constaté que les inondations ont déjà causé un déplacement de 1155 Ménages.

Dans la nuit du 02 au 03 Mai 2023, une forte pluie tombée toute la nuit a occasionnée encore une fois la montée et le debordement de la rivière Rusizi. Tous les ménages des collines Kinyinya1, kinyinya2, mushasha1  mushasha2 et Gaharawe  sont inondés, même les 200 méages qui avaient reçu les abris d'urgence sont inondés et les volontaires sont à l'oeuvre pour les déplacer et reinstaller les abris dans le même site mais à un endroit non inondé. 

Parmi ces 1155 ménages déplacés, 476 ont été accueils dans les ménages voisins tandis 679 ménages sont logés dans le Site des déplace de Kinyinya dans la même commune.

Actuellement, 2920 ménages sont sans abris et la Platforme a décidé de les relocaliser vers le site de déplacés de SOBEL.

Ces inondations ont aggravé l’évolution de l’épidémie de cholera en cours et qui, malgré la tendance de stabilisation, donne plutôt une allure inquiétante avec en moyenne 10 nouveaux cas chaque jour et presque tous de la même localité.

results.name: BDI: Flood - 2023-04 - Burundi: Flood Gatumba 2023
results.summary:
Following heavy rain, the Rusizi River overflowed and caused flooding in 5 hills in the Gatumba Zone. These floods have caused the displacement of 679 households from Kinyinya I, Kinyinya II, Mushasha I and II hills as well as Gaharawe hill. These households have partially or totally destroyed houses.

Currently, these households are in makeshift houses and only 200 have already benefited from family tents and NFI kits from the Burundi Red Cross. The newly displaced are concentrated in the Kinyinya Site2) and others are massed around the Gatumba-Border Road in very unfavourable conditions.

 

It should be noted that the flooding continues to such an extent that there are new households that continue to be affected and consequently increase the number of displaced households.

field_reports.description:
Le Lac Tanganyika touche 5 provinces à savoir Bujumbura, Mairie de Bujumbura, Rumonge et Makamba sur une longueur de 159 Km tout au long des routes RN4 et RN3.
La montée des eaux du Lac Tanganyika est cyclique et la recente montée est celle de 1964 qui a fait le Lac de  783.6 m du niveau de la mereu alors que son niveau est normalement de  777.08 m. 
ACtuelleent, tous les quatre pays se partagean le lac Tanganyika sont affectés et le Burundi est le plus à risque. Les degats et/ou enjeux sont les villeges/quartiers devastés par l'eau du Lac, le deplacement de la population, les risques économiques resultant de l'arret des affaires développés au bord du Lac mais aussi la qualité de l'eau qui est normalement consommée dans les ménages de al Ville de Bujumbura.
